description.text:
Looked online for a Mini/Micro Christmas tree stand but could not find one. Wanted to add some Christmas Cheer to my work desk 
Can be printed on Makerbot
Designed for Small Desktop trees.

UPDATES:
New Base Released! Mini_Christmas_Tree_stand_base V2 has thinner wall & built in M4 NUT. Rounded corner also

Print:
1 X Mini Christmas Tree stand base
4 X Mini Christmas Tree stand leg
4 x Mini Chirstmas Tree stand tree holder Find:
4 X 4mm 35~40mm long Socket head Screw. (or eye screws) 1) Assembly Legs into base (.2mm offset already built in)
2) Screw is 4mm screws
3) Add Caps
4) Find tree
5) Put into stand and lock down
6) Fill with water
7) Add Leds controlled by and arduino

I am in the process of building a Kossel Mini kit. While it is an excellent kit from Sintron on Ebay and Amazon, I am finding the need for parts that are not supplied to make a great and organized build. These are some parts that I made to help the process along:

  • A CPU base and cover for the RAMPS/Arduino boards. The cover is designed to hold a 60mm fan.
  • Some clips and wire guides that clamp into the aluminum channels.
  • A case for the LCD 2004 screen and knob. The first case is for a rocker switch measuring approx. 23mm x 28 mm. The second case is for a switch measuring about 12mm x 28mm. These cases will need to be rotated 90 deg. on the X axis for printing.
  • Some brackets to screw the machine down to a board that line up with the aluminum channels.
  • An improved back plate for the endstop switches.

Special Note: For the CPUBase, you will need to take a fine saw, like a coping or hack saw, and cut down through the pegs about 3mm so they have some spring to clip into the Mega board.

title: Geeetech Prusa I3 X Y Idler & Tensioner

description.text:
Geeetech Prusa I3 X 8mm Acrylic Y Idler & Tensioner is a complete rethink after few mishaps with my first tensioner support bracket remix would catch the Y carriage occasionally.

This was inspired by reading about pulley systems for another project but then finding Crowned Pulley by DaleDunn http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14117

Note: the pic of the crowned pulley was my test that was too tight and I used a heat gun to fit the bearings... the printed part should be a good snug fit and wound look distorted. Saying that though I did 20 hours of print without a problem despite it being wonky.

This is designed to use the Original Bracket etc from Geeetech and 624ZZ (2off 4mmx13mmx5mm).

Parts:
M3 cap head x25mm
M3 Nylock
M3 square flat nut supplied by Geeetech
M3 Washer

I filed the Cap Head Bolt head down for belt clearance and just enough to get an Alan key to grip. I used the square M3 nut as a locknut on the pulley bracket. Between the spacer and Thumb wheel I used M3 washer.

The most important thing is to get the Original metal U bracket to engage into the square hole in the acrylic front but not so far as to have the belt pinch on the hole to and bottom. The second thing is to make sure the belt is not too long that the idler bracket with the small square M3 nut doesn't bottom out before you have belt tension.

I recommend you use a Y Carriage Belt Holder that you can easily adjust the belt length as the original setup from the kit is difficult having to punch holes in the belt.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PDiU9ghSkDo

Added idler to take MR84zz but I am unable to test this... may work as the other.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3 X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

comments.text: Have to modify this as my Geeetech uses MR84ZZ bearings which means the diameter of the bearing is 8mm.
comments.author: bernbout

comments.text: I sold my Geeetech printer but you could buy 10 x 624zz from china for $1 and $1.25 postage
comments.author: bernbout

comments.text: Are the 624zz the same size as the MR84ZZ? If so why a different name/number for them do you know?
comments.author: ant0ny

comments.text: No different size. I have added a modded version to take the MR84zz bearing but I can't test this so see how it goes.
comments.author: bernbout

comments.text: I printed this modded version but had to enlarge the bearing holes slightly as the bearing would not fit. Fitted it and for a small object it printed ok. However when I did a large object like across the whole bed diagonally, the belt started rubbing against the side on the metal and I had to kill the print. It appears to me that this works if the bracket is dead perpendicular. Then the belt moves to the centre even if you move the belt. But if the bracket is just off perpendicular (or you move the bracket) then the belt just wanders to the opposite side and rubs against the bracket. Had to refit my original pulley. Thanks anyway.
comments.author: ant0ny

comments.text: In the instructions I mention
comments.author: bernbout

comments.text: Thanks for your advice. Yes, I also realised that with this pulley the U bracket was not fully and properly seated in the square hole and this was causing the bracket to sort of move sideways causing the belt to rub. Unfortunately, the diameter of this rounded pulley is greater than the original pulley, and so the current belt is just not long enough to allow the bracket to seat fully into the square hole. I have some belt material on order so when it arrives from China, I will give this another go as it seems a real feasible option.
comments.author: ant0ny

comments.text: I have run this mod for 5 weeks now and in the last I have just gone through 1kg role of filament printing my new Wilson II frame parts. I haven't had to touch the setup since I installed it.
comments.author: ant0ny

The Nautilus from the Shellter project was really cool, so I sliced it and added an ring to it.  However, I wanted to do something that only a 3D printer could do, so I scrapped that and made this from scratch instead.  While making the outline I made her name in the center, to make them uniquely hers.  
I know that that move doesn't help 99.9% of you out there. She didn't notice her name until I told her, so maybe yours won't notice either!  
Update:  I've added files for a shell without a name (but have not tested them).

Scale. Print.  Dip.  
I printed it without raft or supports on my Up!  
I dipped it a few times in acetone.

comments.text:
Prints great in gold PLA from BilbyCNC!
I had to print the way up you have it facing - when printing upside-down the UP added some smudgy stuff around the edge on 1st layer -could not turn it off - no matter what support settings!

V2 of my NH cribbage board. V1 can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1411418

I have made the holes further apart to make the board more durable, as well as broken them into groups of 5. This means the board has to be 10% bigger, but still fits on a 1x8 inch piece of rough cut lumber.

This can be printed without supports from the STL. If you want the cad file get it from grabcad https://grabcad.com/library/466010

When I get access to a glow-forge I'll probably add in some etching.
It's an Iphone 5s phone case boi! With an ouroboros etching on the back. Made by your friendly neighborhood high school student.

This is a sailboat based on Sunfish and Laser designs.  I'm planning on building a full size one with my Daughter so I drew this up and and built it to see how it goes together.

I used 1/32" plywood available at hobby stores.  Good old "Elmers" is my glue of choice for wood, long working time and fills gaps a mile wide.  Cut everything out on the laser and start the build by gluing up the centerboard trunk.  I left the bow end open so I could stick the mast down between the sides and hold it in place.  Use the two small rectangles to space the sides of the trunk, leaving a gap big enough to fit the centerboard.  Glue the bulkheads to the underside of top, notch the back two to fit the stringers that run lengthwise from the front of the cockpit to the transom. The sides and bottom pieces will need trimming for a good fit, take your time. I used a piece of hardwood for the mast after breaking several balsa ones.  To hold the tiller in place I found a small hinge for a dollhouse and used very small nails to hold it in place.

comments.text: I'm thinking about getting a filastruder in the near future.  What is your honest opinion on the quality of the filament it produces?  Is it able to keep a consistent diameter and stuff?
comments.author: steveweber314

comments.text: Hi, I bought it 2 months ago and I'm very satisfied about it, the product is good and can give you a good quality, but (as everything) it's necessary to make experience using it; I immediately start to produce, but I need 4/5 sessions to find the right setup for temperature, filament diameter, feed system, size of crushed plastic parts. The filament quality is good I'm able to keep diameter between 1.60/1.85 mm and my printer extruder "eats" it without problems, but I better every time. I use Cycolac MG94 pellet mixed with parts of wrong printed items and the quality is much better the Esun ABS I used before.

description.text: This is number 3 in my weekly earring quest. This is my 3D interpretation of the "Hunger Games" Mockingjay logo.  It looks dissimilar enough that it could just be a neat earring.  I haven't read the Hunger Games books (edit: just read them), but my girlfriend loves them.  I hope she loves this too!

Printing this one is a little tricky.  I deliberately didn't think about how it would be printed when I made it, which resulted in a lot of support testing.  Placing the bird on it's head actually works really well.
Print the bird.  Print the ring. Dip in Acetone. Wire together.  Exhale. 
I have included the !Up file for the bird with the orientation that worked best for me.  Make sure you print two birds at the same time to give the tail feathers a chance to cool between layers and/or install a fan.

remixed_from.author: Parkinbot
remixed_from.title: Cut your own gears with profile shift - OpenSCAD library

description.text:
I have made this for a test of Parkinbot's gearcutting library.

Please print this only with XY-size compensation of your printer. You don't know what I mean? Please print the testcube first. If you'll get a cube with X and Y is 20mm and the hole is 10mm, then it's all right. If your testcube is >=20.1mm and the hole is <=9.9mm then don't continue. Look for the parameter of XY-size-compensation in your slicing software and adjust this (slic3r and repsnapper has). If you don't adjust this, this object doesn't fit. In this case, other people write in their thing: sandpaper this. (good luck at the gears). I will go back to the basics: look for precision of your machine. My machine is an opensource machine and it provides precision. Your machine is a commercial machine and it doesn't provide precision??? At this website, the people works very different: some include a big gap in the stl and I have a rattle-precision print. Some like to have 20mm when they write 20mm, and it will not fit sometimes. -> see screenshot of slic3r. I use version 1.2.9 on linux.

STL files: gears.scad is copied and adjusted a little. pins.scad is the well known idea, but rewritten in the most cases. Holder is not very important, it works without holder.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vRwl8jhBfac

edit 2016-12-12 4.stl was wrong. Now corrected and uploaded..

comments.text: Nice model, I'm printing this but I just found out that you have included the wrong STL file for gear 4. It is a duplicate of gear 3, instead of the correct model. Easy to generate from OpenSCAD, and it appears that printing a mirror copy of gear 0 will also work, but it would be nice if you could correct this.

title: X-Carriage for Toranado Prusa i3 8mm LM8LUU 45mm Bearing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I built it from ground up using 123Design, similar to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1302584
It is for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246951. (other holes maybe added for other extruder, let me know).I been told that should be able to mount any extruder to that that uses the 23x23mm hole pattern. (The NEMA17 "Wade" i3 rework, etc) thank Toranado3D.

I changed to work with 45mm bearing LM8LUU, added adjustable belt works with Wanhao or similar that don't use adjuster and even 2.5mm belt can be use (not tested), cable hole seem work without anything to tie to.

Showing in detail, I have added adjuster to tight the belt (not forgetting a tiewrap), and didn't need support apart where the bridge are need to remove. Suitable for 45mm bearings, Having GT2 belt but also 2.5mm belt too. On Wanhao, belt is slightly too short so it need replacing that belt (check it first).

You need to follow the photo. Break off the corner, clean up with a hot iron. Push in Brass Knurl Nuts with a hot iron, flush to the surface and quickly use the screw to straighten.

To test the belt, connect up the GT2 belt, the adjuster have a washer with 20mm screw, put in GT2 belt in before screw in, check the photo.

You are ready to put it in, it is require that LM8LUU is set up. Put in the base and slide in both LM8LUU, you see the bearings slides in makes it locked in but still loose. Fit the covers with 22mm screws, don't put it up too tight but just enough to grip, and slides fully to see it moves freely.

If you have belt ready that to added in make sure it is the right length which you can screw in, readjust the length if it too short or too long, make sure the screw isn't cut in the belt on the other side, don't put in tiewrap just yet till it is bearly tight then put tie wrap at the end of the aduster to holds both belt in and out of adjuster and that won't slip then cut off the excess, then to adjust till it is correct. Slide the carriage end to end and free from loose objects.

Free to put on the Toranado extruder.

Only find it quick to put it on in say 5 minutes. It took me a long time designing and few rejects that I made in the past week is now paid off.

Parts required
5x M3 22mm screws
1x M3 20mm screw
6x M3x4mm Brass Knurl Nuts
1x M3 plain washer
1x tiewrap 2.5mm 100mm
2 x LM8LUU (45mmx15mmx8mm)

2 extra piece of thin layers for testing for x_stop switch, the one with a bump is for Wanhao I3D, X-CARRIAGE_45mm_thin_sw, put this between the extruder and the carriage, add a switch for x-stop by screw (M2 screws and drill 1.5mm hole), glue or tiewrap

title: Atom Armor for RotorX Atom RX122 3MM with supports

description.text:
This is a remix of the excellent atom armor boots by spencergcs. I chose the remix from Puppetx with supports to base my remix on.

My remix is simply stretched on the Z axis to increase the height of the part to make it suitable for the thicker 3MM atom frame. This frame variant is available from ParagonUAV and possibly other sources.

The thicker frame is for 1306 motors and with the heavier build, I think the protection is even more important.

Netfabb

I used the Netfabb scale tool to increase Z axis from 5.0MM to 5.76MM. I arrived at this height by using a ratio of part height to frame thickness (5.0MM/2.6MM -> 5.76MM/3.0MM).

title: Bristol Stool Chart, Inspired by Dr. Oz

description.text:
You know they (whomever 'they' may be) are full of crap...but do you know what KIND of crap they are full of?

With this new 3D-Printable Bristol Stool Chart inspired by the one seen on Dr. Oz, you can now know not only what kind of Crap they are full of, but also be able to tell the health of their gastrointestinal tract!

While I considered selling this design/3-D printed model, the overwhelming consensus from the community was that this was "way too gross" and "icky" to be sold online.

However, I can't help but believe that somewhere out there though, someone needs this chart. Thus, I am releasing it out into the world to be used non-commercially for the health benefit of gastrointestinal tracts everywhere.

So you know, Dr. Oz says 3-4 is the healthy range you want to be in.

Post Printing

How I designed this

I sculpted and modeled each piece of poo from primitives inside of Meshmixer and Tinkercad.

author: Athanaze

title: PRUSA i3 Plate Adjust & Support Brace - Self Aligning

description.text:
UPDATE 13-MAY-2016: added Lower brace support with 10mm hole, for using on PRUSA machines with M10 threaded rods. Use M8 threaded rods for the brace supports. Also revised the upper support, it now is stronger under the hex adjuster, and has a larger hex size ... should allow more adjust-ability without risk of breakage.

Adjust perpendicularity of PRUSA i3 Aluminum plate to your print bed, and brace the plate too!!! Provided there is a self-aligning & self assembled joint system for supporting & adjusting your PRUSA i3 plate ... improves print quality by preventing flexing of the unsupported plate, and let's you adjust perpendicularity of the plate (not even possible in original PRUSA design!). This is a major design flaw in the i3 Aluminum Plate design, the plate bends and moves even at low printing accelerations ... and there is NO way to adjust perpendicularity of the Aluminum plate to the print bed! Solutions for this design deficiency are difficult because of the variations in angles from one i3 build to another due to variable positioning of M10 threaded rods in Y direction under print bed. NOW, there is a FIX for your i3 Aluminum Plate printer ... a one size fits all solution, that provides plate support bracing and a perpendicularity adjustment feature! Give it a try, good luck!

Original released files here are for machines using M8 threaded rods, some rework models use M10 (working on STL files for M10 now, be patient).

Build Tip - M8 threads are in these models, but will only print crudely, if the treads don't function well ... heat an M8 screw, turn it into your printed part, let it cool down .. perfect threads! (don't over heat the screw and destroy your part) .. or simply tap the threads with a tapping tool. (the top adjustor will be difficult to turn if there is too much friction on the M8 threads) These STL files are designed to be printed without support material. Some force may be required to free up the "ball and socket" feature after printing these parts, make sure your extruder flow rate is optimal, as over extruding will create a part where the ball and socket feature will not be movable after printing!

comments.text: So I have an i3 rework. It has M8 smooth rods, and M10 threaded rods. Were you saying you may publish files to work with that as well?
comments.author: Toranado3D

comments.text: Correct ... the 2nd design will be a set of parts designed for M10 threaded rods.  Also I will be increasing the adjustor nut size and material thickness around the adjusting nut, or adding a knob there instead ... so more torque can be applied to the adjustor.
comments.author: Toranado3D

comments.text: Hi BigCooter
comments.author: BigCooter

comments.text: I just uploaded a lower support with a 10mm hole, for receiving a M10 threaded rod ... try using this on PRUSA machines with M10 threaded rods .. but use a M8 threaded rod for the brace support.  Also note that I increased the strength of the upper support, it has a larger hex for adjusting, and is stronger under that hex feature .. the original twisted a bit here if some force was required to straighten up your PRUSA i3

title: IKEA GRUNDTAL Knife Rack Damage Free Tape / Command Strip Mount

description.text:
This is an alternative standoff that allows the IKEA GRUNDTAL knife rack to be mounted using double sided tape or Command strips instead of drywall screws. I rent and have a granite backsplash, so I needed an alternative to screw mounting.

Be mindful of weight when using this. My knives are pretty light. Heavier knives may cause trouble / injury.

You'll need all of the following:

  • 2x M3x10mm machine screws
  • 2x M3 nuts
  • 2x M3 washers
  • 2x Small Command strips (or some double sided tape)

Attach the mount to the GRUNDTAL mounting bracket with the machine screws as shown in the photos. The head of the M3 screw should be flush with the back surface of the standoff. Attach to wall with tape.

The "special request" file was made for a user in the comments. It's made for medium sized Command strips and will stick out significantly from behind the rack. It's bulky but may work for you.

title: EdTracker Case for V2 PCB and MPU 9250

description.text:
So i picked up an EDTracker kit and the V2 PCB before realising that the switch would not fit on the board with the MPU 9250 which came with the kit. Rather than loose the switch i decided to wire it to the board and build a case to hold the switch.
Its not very elegant but it did the job.

The PCB and switch mounting are a tight fit as i did not want them moving around, in my case one of the retaining arms for the switch cracked when i was pushing in the switch, this may vary with each printer, mine didn't make the switch post that great (a few globs on it). I little spot of super glue fixed the cracked arm.

After i had put everything together i shrunk the latches on the lid a little in case it would print a little too tight. It stays in place but may be a little loose. ( A little electrical tape can fix that.)

title: Z Axis Anti wobble for Prusa I3

description.text: Inspired by Radus' part I re-did it from scratch to fit my needs. I had a pretty bad wobble on my left side from a slightly bent z threaded rod. I could also see where the nuts were wearing from being bound so tight in the x carriage and not being able to move with the bends in the rod. Here is a video that shows my rod and the wobble it has with the part installed: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qlw363e1z_k This version has an opening that will fit two M5 nuts (spread apart) and then I inserted a 7mm diameter spring that pushes the two nuts apart. This basically adds anti-backlash on the nuts / z rod also.

I removed the existing nuts then widened the threaded rod hole just a little to keep the rod from rubbing on the x carriage parts (we are trying to limit the movement of the x carriage ends. Install the two M5 nuts with a spring between them. I think I got mine from a variety pack from Home Depot. They were about 7mm x 10m and compressed to less than 4-5mm. This will allow the bottom nut to push down on the top of the threads and the top nut to push onto the bottom of the threads. The notch in the end is where the 8mm smooth rod is used as a guide and keeps it from rotating. I had a bad wobble on the left rod and will upload a video soon.

That means you can get rid of the springs in the bed!!!!! comments.text: I've just printed these, but haven't attached them yet, because I'm trying to figure out how they are supposed to work - by taking the nut out of the x ends, will there not be even more wobble now? comments.author: GtwoK

comments.text: Yeah, your missing the problem. The smooth rods are what guide the x carriage up and down (Z) and should be straight. The threaded rods tend to have some bend or defects in them and if they are constrained to the carriage using the z nut then any wobble the rods have will cause the X carriage to move a little. By isolating the threaded rods using this part the X carriage just sits on top of this part and the part can wobble all it wants from the Z threaded rod but the carriage will not wobble because it is just resting on this part. The weight of the X carriage pulls it down when the Z lowers. Another good advantage I have seen is you can't crash the extruder into the bed anymore because when the extruder nozzle hits the bed and the Z keeps moving the X carriage will stop because it is not tied to the nut anymore. You can also lift the carriage up quickly by hand if you need to. You should be able to watch the video and see the wobble and isolation I had.

title: Dynam C-47 DC3 Model Steerable Tailwheel

description.text:
Aircraft: Dynam C-47  / Dynam DC-3
The original plastic tail wheel was not steerable, so I printed out a new, stronger bracket and made the tail wheel steerable by adding an additional linkage to the rudder servo.  The throw is adjustable.

Print.  Bend first part of wire, insert through bracket.  Bend 90 degrees, insert over wire a small piece of tubing to keep the wheel from falling downwards.  Add a servo control horn wire capture thingie (my mind is drawing a blank for the actual name).  Make a loop in the wire linkage and attach to this.  Glue in plane.  Steer on ground and have controllable take off rolls.
You'll need a replacement tail wheel (you could use the original one, but it is hard plastic and not grippy), wire, misc hardware.

This is a reasonably accurate 1/32 scale model of a second-generation Smart ForTwo.
Why?
Because I still have more walker mechanisms than I know what to do with, and one of these waddling around was a fun mental image. Judge for yourself https://vine.co/v/hi6r6KM16iu
Decide if you want to print one with or without the cavity for the walker mechanism, then print the bodyshell, 4 wheels and 4 pins.

author: Wiredgen

description.text:
Thanks to maddin_2 for his wonderful pot! I have searched for many different designs and this was the only real working design where it prints well with the needed extraction point to point print. Others created a mess and wasted plastic. He has the right shape of netting, thick enough, strong enough and prints well. great work! :)

I shrunk it down to a standard 2" pot and sliced off the extra rim to fit my needs in my hydroponics garden. I have already printed 30+ of these and I find that any more than 4 at a time creates failed prints. 4 seems to me the magic number at 30 mm/sec max speed.

For sizing, my version is the exact same dimentions as this pot
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00I1OCZLY

author: cyril50

description.text:
"Japanese Erasers" have been very popular with kids for a several years, as have keychains that hang in bunches on the outside of backpacks. I find both, though the erasers in particular, to be excellent 3D learning tools. When taken apart they're reduced to basic 3D shapes that can be modeled on the computer then reconstructed as 3D printed objects, which are wonderful keepsakes of their introductory modeling class. I also consider joinery to be an important early skill for young inventors to develop. So the most interesting designs in my class are those that consist of multiple pieces that are interesting whether together or as a pile of printed parts. The creation of this simple object, together with others that I've uploaded to Thingiverse, are useful exercises for anybody learning 3D modeling.
Bob Krause
Inventor Studios
Berkeley, CA
my first name at inventorstudios dot com

I've printed this in ABS with 3 skins, 20% fill and .20mm resolution. The cap is printed with supports, the inside with a raft, but the base without either.
I like a tight fit between parts. So the tolerance of this model is .50mm. If you're interested in evolving this, the model source is available on Tinkercad.com.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed it as it appears.
